entry.title: how to send multiple pull request on Github
entry.summary:
Last day I had this situation where I was required to send multiple pull requests to a open source project. All my previous attempts were turning futile as the commits were getting stacked in a single PR (Pull Request). As I searched through Stackoverflow pages I realized I had to create different branches to request multiple PRs. Here are the steps:

  1. You need to create a new branch at first:

    git checkout -b new-branch-name

  2. Now you will have to select a previous commit from where you wish to make changes. This can be from the SHA where the original project was forked:

    git cherry-pick SHA-hash-of-commit

You can get SHA-hash of your commits from:

git log

Alternativly you can even do:

git log --pretty=format:'%h'

to get all SHA-hash but you have to be aware which SHA-hash will work for you.

  1. Make the relative changes and push them (after git add & git commit):

    git push origin new-branch-name

And then you can view the new branch from your Github profile, switch to it and make the pull request.

entry.title: Fedora 19 booting into emergency mode [cause and possible solution(s) ]
entry.summary:
Booting up my laptop one morning, I found my usual Fedora 19 login screen missing. Instead I found Fedora emergency screen staring at me. It looked something like this (there were few more lines there):

Welcome to emergency mode.
Use "systemctl default" or ^D to activate default mode.
Type “journalctl” to view system logs.
Give root password for maintenance:
(or type Control-D to continue)

As a normal Linux user I tried entering the commands printed on the screen, also looked into the logs for further clue as what exactly went wrong. As I remember I was playing around with the Apache configuration and updated the file systems, day before yesterday. To my dismay any of the commands mentioned in the emergency mode didn't gave any clue.

Searching on the internet gave me some clues that I might need to boot from a live cd/pen-drive to work around. But the problem was that the fedora copy was inside my system. I found many forums which had incomplete solutions for the same.

At last I headed for #fedora channel on IRC and Renich was kind enough to help me with the issue.

The following mentioned steps will also help you understand triggering of emergency mode on Fedora and possibly steps to resolve the same.

What causes an emergency mode to appear

There can be many reasons for triggering of emergency mode such as improper shut down of system, power issues etc. Quoting according to fedora

When things go wrong, there are ways to fix problems.
However, these methods require that you understand the system well.
This chapter describes how to boot into rescue mode, single-user mode,
and emergency mode, where you can use your own knowledge to repair
the system

Oviously I did some nasty things with my system,it might be my system upgradation. But the good news is that you can figure out the real cause of the issue. All you need to do is keep your eyes open. Operating system (here Fedora ) tend to give us reasons for doing anything.

Try pressing 'ctrl+d' to exit and see if there is an error message written. In my case the OS asked me to do manual fsck on the corrupted disk/file system. Something like this:

systemd-fsck[576]: /dev/sda1: UNEXPECTED INCONSISTENCY; RUN fsck MANUALLY.
systemd-fsck[576]: (i.e., without -a or -p options)

The above error message showed me that /dev/sda1 partition needs manual fsck. Another search on the internet gave me how to do fsck in fedora But unfortunatly that didnt solved my problem.

Solution(s) if any???

  1. The first solution can be following the steps written on the screen. One of them being 'ctrl+d'. Try pressing this again and again and you might resolve the issue. I tried this and I did saw the login screen couple of times.

Try rebooting; sometimes, it gets fixed just like that.

If you are still stuck move onto the next step.

  1. As per solution I need a manual fsck on my partition:

    $ fsck.ext4 /dev/sda1

and type y for everything asked. What this did was to repair the filesystem to normal. Oviously I had no idea what was all 'y' for but hey! everything is learning experience, one day I might understand those as well.

  1. Another solution can be typing

    fsck -A

in emergency mode and it might help.

NOTE: Don't just blindly copy paste the commands mentioned above look for the error messages. Your file system might be different as compared to mine. For example I had sda1 and ext4 while you might have ext3 or 2. difference between ext2 ext3 ext4 In my case sda1 partition got a bit screwed and it needed an fsck,look for your issue.

In case steps 2 and 3 work out well for you, try a reboot and hopefully everything will be back to normal.

entry.title: How to Install and configure Apache on Fedora 19
entry.summary:
Few days back I was juggling to install the apache web server on my local machine which has fedora 19. Information on the internet is scattered around and there isn't one tutorial which can you through the entire process. It tooks me quite some time to figure out the exact procedure and the below mentioned steps are the result of that.

I assume you have a previous knowledge of vim and its subsequesnt commands, if not this tutorial might help you.

Installing Apache webserver

1:

sudo yum install httpd

Configure Apache to run your local website

2:

vim /etc/httpd/conf/httpd.conf

Browse to the end of file (you do not need to change anything else) and append the following at bottom:

<VirtualHost *:80>
DocumentRoot /var/www/your-site-name
ServerName local.your-mysite-name
</VirtualHost>

Add your site (folder) name to DocumentRoot and ServerName. For example in my case it would be /var/www/site and local.site

Note: whatever site/folder-name you are adding above, must exists. If its not create such folder. After adding the above, you can save and close the file.

3:

vim /etc/hosts

Append the following to the file:

127.0.0.1    local.your-site-name

For example in my case it will be: local.mysite. Now, save and close the file.

  1. Start Apache:

    sudo service httpd start

  2. Check if apache is running or not:

    sudo service httpd status

  3. Run:

    ps -eZ | grep httpd

to view the httpd processes

You can now access your site at the address you specified above, e.g. local.your-site-name .

Note: do not add www at the start.

entry.title: How to configure PhoneGap in Fedora 19
entry.summary:
Building android apps in native Java is cool but the only problem with this methodology is that you cannot port the same into other platforms (like Facebook, Windows etc). This drawback can be effectively removed if you use HTML5, CSS3 and Javascript to build the mobile apps. This is where PhoneGap comes in handy.

The installation page of Phonegap gives some instruction on how to install some dependencies.

Npm and NodeJS

  1. To install Node you need to install some dependencies such as c++/gcc, which is used in compilation of the former:

    $ sudo yum install gcc-c++

then install node. You can either do:

$ yum install nodejs

  1. or you can install it from the source files.

    a: Download the source code from the website.

    b:

    $ cd Downloads

    c:

    $ tarnode-v0.8.15.tar.gz (change the versions accordingly)

    d:

    $ cd node-v0.8.15

    e:

    $ ./configure && make && sudo make install

    f: Add the path in system, if its not present:

    $ cd

$sudo vi .bash_profile

    add these lines in the file:

    PATH = $PATH:/usr/local/bin

export PATH

  2. Now that you have node, installation of npm will be very easy.

    • get the source from Github

    • untar it, move into that directory and then:

      $ ./configure && make && sudo make install

4:

$ sudo npm install -g phonegap

  1. Phonegap should be installed now. Move into a directory where you wish to create a app:

    $ phonegap create my-app

$ cd myapp

$ phonegap run android

At this moment if you have a mobile device connected to the system the app will be installed on the device itself.

entry.title: entrepreneurship vs job
entry.summary:
Today while I was loitering around, few conversations (from the past) made me smile. yes I also decided I would also write a piece on this.

why our Indian culture promotes the culture of job searching instead of creating jobs for others, why not create a company instead of opting for MBAs and post grad degrees? My parents like any all caring parents in India wants me to take up a job after I complete my B.tech, which is quite natural considering the fact that they have invested in me for many years and now they wish I should live a happy and peaceful life. This is what any parent will wish for his/her child, right ? Perfectly normal

But why not the other way around? Like how interesting it would have been if had they asked me to create a company instead of looking for jobs. (By the way I had already created one and its shut down as well. poor me!)

You see, I examined the generations of my family history and no one had ever diverted from the searching-the-job attitude after college (I will be the first one perhaps). So, no one knows what its like there, this entrepreneurship is total mystery land for them. And people are afraid from stepping into unknown places. Perfectly normal

Well, then how we could change things around? entry.title: Testing production apps on mobile
entry.summary:
Assuming you have ADB and Eclipse IDE installed.

I am using Samsung Galaxy Pro to connect to fedora 19 but it shouldn't really matter if you have a different device.

In the eclipse toolkit, you have the option to run it directly on a device. It's rather quick to do so but the experience is same as that of emulator. On your phone:

  1. Enable USB debugging (modern android versions this is present as Developers Option ) as well as installation of apk from sources other than the market (in the settings > security option).

  2. In the AndroidManifest.xml file , add:

    android: debuggable="True"

to the <application> element.

  1. Connect your device with your system via USB cable, then Open terminal:

    $ adb devices

you will get a unique id for the device attached. Keep a note of this id, we will be using this below.

  1. You need to add a udev rules file that contains a USB configuration for each type of device you want to use for development. In the rules file, each device manufacturer is identified by a unique vendor ID, as specified by the ATTR{idVendor} property. For a list of vendor IDs, see vendor ids .

Log in as root and create this file: /etc/udev/rules.d/51-android.rules.

And Use this format to add each vendor to the file:

SUBSYSTEM=="usb", ATTR{idVendor}=="0bb4", MODE="0666", GROUP="plugdev"

In this example, the vendor ID is for HTC, change it according to your device.

Now execute:

chmod a+r /etc/udev/rules.d/51-android.rules
  1. Your device is now configured, when testing apps from Eclipse IDE select this device when prompted.

Other ADB uses

After step 4 above, type:

$ adb shell

this will list the root contents of your phone. Next if you do:

$ ls

All the files will be visible to you. Other operations such as: cd, mkdir etc are also applicable.

If you wish to know more about ADB operations type $ adb in your terminal, you will get all available commands to play with.
